name: The Strategist
shortDescription: Decisive planners who combine clear direction with thorough preparation.
narrative: As a Strategist, you bring together decisive leadership with meticulous planning. You don't just set ambitious goals‚Äîyou create detailed roadmaps to achieve them. Your combination of confidence and thoroughness makes you particularly effective at turning vision into executable action. You're the person teams turn to when they need both direction and a concrete plan.
strengths: Creating comprehensive plans with clear action steps and accountability
Making confident decisions backed by thorough analysis and preparation
Holding yourself and others to high standards while maintaining forward momentum
Anticipating obstacles and developing contingency plans before problems arise
blindSpots: May come across as overly controlling or micromanaging when stressed
Can struggle to delegate because of high standards for both outcomes and process
Might resist improvisation or course corrections once a plan is in place
teamRole: You serve as the architect of team success, providing both vision and structure. You excel at breaking down complex initiatives into manageable steps and ensuring everyone understands their role. Your team appreciates your ability to anticipate what's needed and plan accordingly.
leadershipStyle: You lead through clear expectations and organized execution. You set ambitious targets and create the systems to achieve them. Your direct reports know exactly where they stand and what's expected, though they may sometimes wish for more flexibility or spontaneity.
stressTriggers: Last-minute changes that disrupt carefully laid plans
Team members who miss deadlines or don't follow established processes
Situations requiring quick decisions without adequate information
copingStrategies: Build buffer time into plans to accommodate unexpected changes
Practice delegating smaller decisions to trusted team members
Develop comfort with 'good enough' solutions when perfection isn't feasible
Schedule regular check-ins rather than trying to control every detail

name: The Visionary
shortDescription: Boundary-pushing innovators who transform ideas into breakthrough solutions.
narrative: As a Visionary, you see connections and possibilities that others miss. Your mind naturally generates novel solutions to complex problems, and you have the adaptability to pursue them even when the path forward is unclear. You don't just think outside the box‚Äîyou question whether the box was ever necessary. Your combination of creative thinking and flexibility makes you a powerful force for innovation and transformation.
strengths: Generating breakthrough ideas that challenge conventional thinking
Adapting quickly as you learn and discover new possibilities
Inspiring others to see potential in what currently seems impossible
Connecting disparate concepts to create something entirely new
blindSpots: May generate more ideas than you can realistically execute
Can become frustrated with necessary processes or practical constraints
Might lose interest once the initial creative challenge is solved
teamRole: You help teams see beyond current limitations and imagine what's possible. You bring fresh perspectives that break through groupthink and challenge comfortable assumptions. While others execute today's work, you're already thinking about tomorrow's opportunities.
leadershipStyle: You inspire people toward ambitious visions rather than directing detailed execution. You create space for experimentation and don't punish failure when it leads to learning. Your team values your ability to see potential in them and their ideas.
stressTriggers: Rigid environments that discourage experimentation
Being forced to follow established methods without room for innovation
Excessive focus on short-term results over long-term potential
copingStrategies: Partner with detail-oriented colleagues who can help execute your ideas
Set specific criteria for which ideas to pursue versus which to set aside
Build in time for creative exploration even during busy periods
Learn to value incremental progress alongside breakthrough moments

name: The Craftsman
shortDescription: Dedicated artisans who blend meticulous execution with creative excellence.
narrative: As a Craftsman, you combine painstaking attention to detail with genuine creative flair. You're not satisfied with merely completing tasks‚Äîyou strive for excellence in execution while bringing artistry and intentionality to your work. Whether you're designing systems, creating content, or building products, you care deeply about both how things work and how they feel. Your dedication to craft sets the quality standard for everyone around you.
strengths: Producing work that demonstrates exceptional attention to detail and artistry
Developing innovative solutions within practical constraints
Maintaining high standards while bringing creativity to routine tasks
Creating systems and processes that balance efficiency with elegance
blindSpots: May spend excessive time perfecting details that don't significantly impact outcomes
Can become frustrated when others don't share your commitment to quality
Might resist delegation because others won't meet your standards
teamRole: You set the quality bar for your team and inspire others to care about excellence. You notice details others miss and ensure the final product reflects well on everyone involved. While others rush toward deadlines, you advocate for taking time to get things right.
leadershipStyle: You mentor others toward mastery rather than merely assigning tasks. You demonstrate excellence through your own work and provide detailed guidance when coaching others. Your team learns from watching how thoughtfully you approach challenges.
stressTriggers: Pressure to compromise quality for speed
Working with teammates who cut corners or overlook details
Projects where craftsmanship isn't valued or appreciated
copingStrategies: Identify which aspects of quality genuinely matter versus perfectionism
Partner with pragmatic colleagues who help balance excellence with practicality
Educate stakeholders about why craftsmanship saves time and resources long-term
Celebrate incremental improvements rather than demanding perfection immediately

name: The Connector
shortDescription: Relationship builders who create strong networks through empathy and engagement.
narrative: As a Connector, you excel at building bridges between people and ideas. You don't just network‚Äîyou genuinely understand what motivates different individuals and how to bring them together effectively. Your combination of social energy and emotional awareness makes you a natural facilitator and team builder. People feel heard and valued in your presence, and you have an uncanny ability to match people with opportunities and each other.
strengths: Building genuine relationships across diverse teams and stakeholder groups
Reading emotional undercurrents in meetings and addressing unspoken concerns
Creating inclusive environments where different perspectives are welcomed
Facilitating difficult conversations by understanding all sides of an issue
blindSpots: May prioritize harmony over necessary conflict or tough decisions
Can become overwhelmed by others' emotions and needs
Might avoid giving direct critical feedback to preserve relationships
teamRole: You're the glue that holds teams together, especially during transitions or conflicts. You notice when someone is disengaged and reach out. You facilitate connections between people who should know each other. Your team values your ability to maintain morale and resolve interpersonal tensions.
leadershipStyle: You lead through relationships and inclusion. You know your people‚Äîtheir strengths, concerns, and aspirations. Your team feels personally invested in success because you've invested in them. However, you may need to push yourself to make unpopular decisions when necessary.
stressTriggers: Team conflict or interpersonal tensions that you can't immediately resolve
Working in isolation without regular interaction with others
Environments that prioritize tasks over people and relationships
copingStrategies: Set boundaries to avoid taking on everyone's emotional burdens
Practice direct communication even when it feels uncomfortable
Remember that healthy conflict can lead to better outcomes
Schedule time for relationship-building even during busy periods

name: The Catalyst
shortDescription: Dynamic mobilizers who drive action through confident engagement.
narrative: As a Catalyst, you combine social energy with confident direction to mobilize people toward bold goals. You're not just a networker‚Äîyou're someone who builds relationships specifically to drive action and results. You know how to read a room, identify what needs to happen, and inspire people to make it happen. Your ability to connect with others while maintaining clear direction makes you particularly effective at leading change and building momentum.
strengths: Building coalitions and getting buy-in for ambitious initiatives
Reading group dynamics and adjusting your approach to move people forward
Inspiring confidence and commitment through personal connection and clear direction
Turning relationships into productive collaborations and partnerships
blindSpots: May move people toward action before they're fully ready or committed
Can become frustrated when others don't share your sense of urgency
Might prioritize relationship-building over relationship depth
teamRole: You're the energizer who gets people moving and keeps momentum going. You identify blockers and either remove them yourself or connect people who can work together to solve problems. Your team appreciates your ability to maintain energy and optimism even during challenging periods.
leadershipStyle: You lead through inspiration and activation. You build relationships quickly and use them to drive toward results. Your team knows what needs to happen and feels motivated to make it happen, though they may sometimes need you to slow down and provide more detailed guidance.
stressTriggers: Slow-moving processes or bureaucratic obstacles that prevent action
Team members who don't engage or commit to shared goals
Working in isolation without opportunities to energize and mobilize others
copingStrategies: Practice patience and give people adequate time to process and commit
Develop deeper relationships rather than constantly building new ones
Balance your drive for action with appreciation for thoughtful deliberation
Focus on quality of engagement rather than quantity of connections

name: The Analyst
shortDescription: Thorough thinkers who deliver insights through careful analysis and measured judgment.
narrative: As an Analyst, you bring together meticulous attention to detail with careful, risk-aware judgment. You don't just gather data‚Äîyou dive deep to uncover insights others miss, and you do so with a clear understanding of potential pitfalls and consequences. Your combination of thoroughness and caution makes you invaluable when decisions carry significant consequences. You're the person others turn to when they need to understand all the angles before moving forward.
strengths: Conducting thorough analysis that uncovers insights others miss
Identifying risks and potential problems before they materialize
Maintaining focus on complex problems without rushing to premature solutions
Producing accurate, well-documented work that withstands scrutiny
blindSpots: May over-analyze situations where quick decisions are needed
Can get caught in details and lose sight of broader strategic context
Might be reluctant to share insights before feeling they're fully developed
teamRole: You're the expert who ensures decisions are based on solid evidence rather than assumptions. Your team relies on you to catch errors, identify patterns, and provide the depth of analysis needed for important decisions. You help prevent costly mistakes through thorough examination.
leadershipStyle: You lead through expertise and careful guidance. You help others develop strong analytical skills and appreciation for thoroughness. Your team learns to value accuracy and thoughtfulness, though they may sometimes need you to provide direction more quickly.
stressTriggers: Pressure to provide analysis or recommendations before you're ready
Incomplete or poor-quality data that undermines your ability to be thorough
Fast-paced environments that prioritize speed over accuracy
copingStrategies: Develop frameworks for quick assessments when deep analysis isn't feasible
Practice communicating preliminary findings with appropriate caveats
Set clear scopes for analysis to prevent endless investigation
Remember that imperfect information is sometimes enough for good decisions

name: The Creator
shortDescription: Empathetic innovators who craft meaningful experiences through creative insight.
narrative: As a Creator, you blend imaginative thinking with deep empathy to craft experiences, solutions, and works that resonate on an emotional level. You're not just creative‚Äîyou're creatively attuned to how people feel and what they need. Whether you're designing products, creating content, or solving problems, you naturally consider both innovation and human impact. Your work doesn't just function well; it connects with people.
strengths: Designing solutions that are both innovative and emotionally resonant
Understanding user needs and translating them into creative approaches
Bringing artistry and humanity to technical or routine work
Creating experiences that people remember and value
blindSpots: May prioritize creative vision over practical constraints
Can become emotionally attached to your creations, making feedback difficult
Might struggle with aspects of work that feel purely functional or administrative
teamRole: You bring humanity and creativity to everything your team does. You ensure solutions aren't just functional but meaningful. You notice how people respond to what you create and use those insights to make things better. Your team values your ability to make work more engaging and impactful.
leadershipStyle: You lead through inspiration and empathy. You help people connect with the deeper purpose behind their work and bring their own creativity forward. Your team feels valued as whole people, not just workers, which unlocks their full potential.
stressTriggers: Environments that dismiss creativity or emotional factors as unimportant
Working on projects that feel purely functional without human impact
Receiving criticism that feels dismissive of your creative vision
copingStrategies: Seek roles and projects where creativity and empathy are valued
Develop thicker skin around feedback while staying connected to your vision
Partner with pragmatic colleagues who can help with execution details
Remember that constraints often spark more creative solutions than complete freedom

name: The Maverick
shortDescription: Bold trailblazers who chart new territory through confident risk-taking.
narrative: As a Maverick, you combine confident leadership with comfort for risk and uncertainty. You're not reckless‚Äîyou're calculated in your willingness to pursue opportunities others deem too uncertain. You trust your instincts and aren't afraid to challenge conventional wisdom or established practices. Your combination of bold direction and risk tolerance makes you particularly effective at pioneering new initiatives and disrupting stagnant situations.
strengths: Championing bold initiatives that others consider too risky
Making decisive moves with incomplete information when opportunities arise
Learning quickly from failures and adjusting course without hesitation
Inspiring confidence in uncertain ventures through personal conviction
blindSpots: May underestimate genuine risks or fail to adequately prepare for challenges
Can become impatient with necessary caution or thorough planning
Might alienate risk-averse colleagues who feel pressured to move faster than they're comfortable
teamRole: You're the catalyst for bold action and breakthrough thinking. You challenge comfortable assumptions and push boundaries constructively. While others analyze risks, you're willing to try approaches that seem unconventional but promising.
leadershipStyle: You lead through bold vision and personal conviction. You're willing to take calculated risks and stand by your decisions. Your team learns to embrace uncertainty and trust their instincts. However, you need to balance your appetite for risk with appreciation for thoughtful preparation.
stressTriggers: Overly cautious environments where bold ideas are dismissed without consideration
Bureaucratic processes that slow down action and innovation
Working with people who focus on why things won't work rather than how they might
copingStrategies: Develop stronger risk assessment skills to complement your natural boldness
Partner with analytical colleagues who can identify pitfalls you might miss
Practice patience with others who need more time to get comfortable with uncertainty
Remember that calculated risks include preparing for multiple scenarios
